item.title: Making Ringtones Loop on Android
item.description: Update 2012-01-06: ICS appears to have a bug where the end of the file is chopped off, so ringtones do not loop properly. If I find or hear a solution I’ll update again! Update 2010-11-09: Added clarification on why I suggest having a short (sub-10 second) ringtone. You want it to loop, right? =P Following on from my previous articles on ringtones, I’ve finally worked out how to make ringtones loop seamlessly in Android.

item.title: Ogg Vorbis Encoder for Windows
item.description: I not so long ago made a post about using Ogg Vorbis for Ringtones on Android, as it considerably reduces the lag between getting a phone call and the phone actually playing the ringtone. The same goes for music on the device–it just starts playing quicker. Anyway, just now I realised that I didn’t link to any encoders for it. So if anyone wondered what I used to accomplish the task, they’d be stuck!

item.title: Use Ogg Vorbis for Lag-free Ringtones on Android
item.description: Update 2010-06-21: If you want to use custom ringtones in the first place, install Rings Extended from the Android Market, then go to Home Settings Sound & display Phone ringtone. When it asks which application you want to use, select Rings Extended, and check the checkbox so that it doesn't ask you again. This will work anywhere any application asks for you to pick a ringtone, assuming it asks via a standard means!

item.title: Strip ID3v1 Tags from MP3s in Linux
item.description: For kicks I decided to remove all the ID3v1 tags from my music files today. They were just getting in the way and served no useful purpose — since I had perfectly fine ID3v2 tags — so they just had to go. I cooked up a little command to help out here! But first, we need to make sure you have the command that we’re going to need here, id3v2. Install it from the official repositories using your distribution’s package manager.

item.title: Phoenix Wright — Ace Attorney: Trials and Tribulations Soundtrack Download
item.description: That was a mouthful of a title. Over time I’ve played and thoroughly enjoyed the Ace Attorney series of games, from Phoenix Wright to Apollo Justice. But for those of you familiar to the series, you’ll notice that this is the soundtrack for the third game in the series. So why have I posted this one? You see, this soundtrack posting has a small story behind it. A while back a perfectionist of a soundtrack ripper called TheRedPriest ripped the soundtrack and uploaded it to his website.

item.title: Advance Wars 2 Soundtrack Download
item.description: Andy, a Commanding Officer from Advance Wars 2 Ah, Advance Wars 2. What is it about you I thought was so amazing? The lovable, single-minded cast? The deep turn-based strategy? The little battle animations of infantry flying off the screen? Well, okay, all of those things are very good reasons to love the game, but there’s another one that sticks out for me too. The soundtrack! Once I completed the normal campaign and could buy the Sound Room, that was it.
